comments.commentBody: And apparently, he was right then, and it's even worse now.

Interesting coincidence, Michael.  I took my Foundations in Art from another professor who "could be imperious and condescending" and I have the same fond memories.  In fact, of all my Foundations course, his is the one I learned most from and remember most about.

I took a class in critical writing from Hilton Kramer at the Yale Drama School in the '70s. He could be imperious and condescending, but I found him to be smart, witty, and passionate about art. It is ironic that being a champion of Modernism could become a reactionary position in the course of a single career, and many of my classmates thought of him as a staunch conservative. Still, I wrote my paper for him about Manet, and I've been in love with Manet and grateful to Kramer ever since.

He liked Pollock! Whew, what a relief!

He was a dependable voice for high principled plasticism in 1965 amidst the torrent of Pop and Op and Minimalism...Hilton brought the discerning eye of a Monmarte Patrician to his writing. I will miss him.
But, he could make us stop and look at both sides.  We didn't have to agree, only understand.  How does anyone know what to accept and what to like if he doesn't know what to look for?

That Mr Kramer continued to champion Abstract Expressionism--that is, the great enthusiasm of his youth, and never seems to have understood the shallowness and limits of its aesthetics, nor acknowledged its destructive influence, was his great failing as a critic. It remains a failing of the New Criterion to this day. Moreover,  all of this "isms" that he condemned are its progeny.

Kramer's deep political awareness -- his Classical Liberalism -- informed his critical judiciousness and sophistication. It is a pity that his observations over the past three decades are now regarded -- by the "establishment" -- as representing a so-called conservative point of view. In a world of relativism and compromise, his voice represented honesty and integrity -- two qualities now lacking in our social and cultural atmosphere.

Larry - $412 in 1939 is about $6,500 today, and don't forget, they got contracts to work on the strip for a number of years (was it actually at $75,000 a year in 1940's dollars). A question is how sorry should we feel for people who made the best deal they could get, for substantial salary, and didn't save or invest conservatively, but kept going back to the table and renegotiating? (I do now feel very sorry for them, but many others don't and I see their side.)

In all honesty, if I created something but had no clue how to market it, and a producer came to me and said I'll give you $6,500 plus a well-paying job for several years - I'd take it. (I might not have taken it five years ago, but right now, I'd jump on it.)
Sorry, no one would think $6,500 would be enough today, so $412 is a joke.
It's hard to imagine that, even in 1939, that the creators felt that $412 was sufficient for the work and rights being given up?

The problem is not people getting care for which they don't pay.

If you show up at a hospital without insurance you get a bill. With the exception of drug addicts and illegals the vast majority of those bills are paid.

It's that the government pays so little to doctors for Medicare and Medicaid patients. That causes doctors to raise the price for everyone else.

The solution is to convert Medicare and Medicaid to voucher plans which people can add to if they want better care.

Single payer = health care rationing

If the government is the single payer, then it can treat you as badly as it wants. You will have no recourse.

Private insurers are forced to treat customers reasonable well due to competition.
